NAME: Paul Rapatano

COMMENTS

I'm so glad that you have recovered. I'm glad I'm glad I'm glad. I am estatic that Cream will reunite. I don't know if you'll make it to O'l Beantown but one can hope. I have been a fan since I first heard the opening strains of I Feel Free. Cream was a beath of fresh air. So different and ultimately one of the few truely influential musical groups of all time. They are right up there with the Beatles. Cream did for musicianship what the Beatles did for song writing. This is not to sell Creams' (escentially you) song writing short. Though Eric went on to become such a huge international star it was you that was the brains, heart and soul of Cream. It amazes me how important the band is concidering thier short lifespan. What a band! I look forward to the cd and dvd of the concert. How stupid would it be not to produce them! I am saddened to hear of the passing of "your father" D.H.S. A great muscian. I wish you good health and a long life. Keep cranking out the great music. You are unique. Your lifelong fan Paul. PS Your autograph on a brown paper bag (it held beer previously) still hangs, framed on my wall.

NAME: Glenn Flowers

LOCATION: Hesperia, California USA

Date: 1/17/2005

Time: 5:38:37 PM

COMMENTS

Jack, I can only echo the sentiments of all the others writing here. I was a bassist/keyboardist in'68 when I heard Crossroads from Wheels of Fire. I was never the same again.

You generated within me a freedom and spirit of adventure that has served me very well for near forty years. Everytime I plug in the EB-3 I think about what Jack would do if he were here. I am constantly aware of your ethereal presence, scrutinizing and nodding approval of my performance.

Needless to say, you have been my hero both on and off the stage. There will never be another such as you.

Congratulations in whipping the illness. No, your MD's did not know you very well. I do.

In whatever you choose to do, I pray for your happiness. May you be in Heaven a week before Lucifer hears you've passed.

With undying admiration and love, Glenn Flowers-bassist

Jack - what a trip to be posting in your guestbook. It actually makes me like the internet. Which is not easy to do.

Anyway, when I was a bad kid skipping school we used to stay up all night and listen to Harmony Row. Now I'm 46. The other night I stayed up all night listening to Harmony Row with my best friend, a 28 year old punk guitarist.

She was blown away and now she plays the record all the time - and she's the hottest guitarist in the city. There you go. It's an immortal album. I hope you read this guest book and feel good about that.

Because you are one of the only people to bring any kind of real classical music sensibility into pop recordings. No pro-rock bulls**t. It's the real deal.

Keep making records. We need 'em.

-s

NAME: Paul Doyle

LOCATION: Larkhall. Scotland

ADDRESS: pauldoyle@wendyhouse1999.freeserve.co.uk

Date: 1/22/2005

Time: 2:32:50 PM

COMMENTS

Hi Jack

Its been a long time 35 years to be exact.

I knew your Mum Betty well, who could forget her ! obviously thats where you got your sense of fun and lust for life. I would visit her regularly at her home in Chatham in Eastkilbride. She would give me fizzy drinks and biscuits and let me tickle your piano in the living room. She would then sit me down and play me the cassette session tapes that you would regularly send to her and ask me what I thought. I remember in particular the tapes for Hows Tricks. They were such an inspiration to me at my early age.

I remember your Dad Charlie he was a character and a half, he and your Mum would pop over sometimes normally on new years after the bells your Dad would bring his fiddle and that would be that. I lived with my parents in Chatham across from your parents house.

You and I met on a couple of occasions the last time we spoke you had come up to chatham in your Jag SJX. I told you at the time that your music had inspired my to become a singer song writer. I will always remember your advice to me at the time  Dont do it for a living Paul, get a good career and keep your music as a serious hobby

I took your advice and got a job in financial services. Im now 42 and the career that you advised me to get has come in pretty useful to feed my wife three children. However, I have continued to write and record my own stuff at home. I wouldnt mind you having a listen to my stuff and letting me know if I am doomed to a further 25 years in financial services ! ha ha.

I was delighted to hear that you are having a a reunion with Cream as I was a little young first time around and hope to able to get a couple of tickets for the Albert Hall and bring my Son Gregor that would be fantastic !

Well Jack, I will close by saying that I was very sorry to hear how ill you had been last year and I am delighted that you have made such a great recovery. I have so much to thank you for, namely the original inspiration in my song writing which has been the passion of my life. I will never forget and often think fondly of the days spent with your Mum at Chatham.

My very kind regards

Paul Doyle

Jack First of all - I hope that you're well and happy with life, which is by far the most important thing. Next: have just added to my collection of your output with Jet Set Jewel (a TRUE jewel), Songs For A Tailor (very cool and incredibly imaginative), and Doing This ... On Ice (nice and loose in parts, so a real concert - and showing how you preserve/augment the past and constantly build for the future). Thank you for your truly astonishing talent and output. I now almost have your complete output (sounds rude to me!!) with just 3 to go. Finally: the Cream reunion. Someone, somewhere is just making an obscene killing with the tickets. Hopefully you, Ginger and Eric will gain financially and musically what you rightfully deserve - but getting a ticket is now beyond a joke. 35 years on and the final Cream gigs will be rembered as much for the sell out of the true fans as for the significance of the group and its reunion. Sorry to end this mail on a down note but this just hasn't been thought through enough. Cheers all the same my friend - you remain an inspiration to many. Rob

NAME: John Wylam

LOCATION: Bowling Green OH

ADDRESS: JohnWylam@aol.com

Date: 1/29/2005

Time: 2:35:16 AM

COMMENTS

All Bright Blessings to this reunion. It's a wonderful thing and I hope that all involved find this a creative period. There's every good reason to imagine it so. I can't help but imagine what it will sound like. The DVD is going to be incredible. There will be one, I trust....

When I first heard Jack's retrospective live 2-CD set, now already over a decade old, amazingly, it was the augmentation that most struck me, how the music did not suffer. Not to say Cream wouldn't still be able to take off at Mach 15 as a trio (one could imagine the "arrangements" to work in such a way, as one example), just that if we consider the possibilities available now -- anyway, this is just one gentle opinion, but the firm truth is I'll buy the DVD on its release date, and hope that the Rock and Roll HoF footage might even be included if possible.

Finally, though, I'm anxious to see what these three musicians will say to each other through music. It's clear their mutual commication hasn't waned one bit. Their experience in the intervening years will mean everything -- Clapton's very public and all-too-genuine reasons for playing the blues, Baker's long apprenticeship in Africa and afterwards (of course his solo discs are also must-haves), and Jack Bruce's dazzling experiments. What will it all sound like, decades and decades on? I'm breathless. Absolutely breathless. And no expectations at all; this is going to be astonishing.

I am so happy that Messrs. Bruce ,Baker and Clapton have decided to play together again. Since 1968 they have all gone on to different things , with various levels of success. Of course , most people that log onto this site believe Jack Bruce to be the influential musician of that band, and to a certain extent , that is true. We all have his solo albums (if we can get them ) . However, we must not forget that a certain chemistry appears when Eric Clapton and Ginger Baker play with Jack Bruce.Clapton said himself in 1993 that he feels "inspired" by Jack Bruce when he plays beside him. And to paraphrase ,as I can't remember the exact quote " there is that special thing that happens when he (Jack) starts to sing". Break a leg Guys . Play it loud. Dick Heckstall-Smith would have been proud to see two London lads and a Glaswegian playin' the Blues. I wish I could be there. Paul.

Have been waiting so long for the Cream reunion. Me, my dad and brother are big fans and were planning on going to the gig in May. Just got through on the hotline after four hours of waiting to be told everything was sold out, even started at 9AM when it opened. Well disapointed, had no chance on the phone and the web booking didnt even work. NAME: Steev Cursons

LOCATION: UK

ADDRESS: scursons@aol.com

Date: 1/31/2005

Time: 12:49:12 PM

COMMENTS

Cream are playing The Royal Albert Hall in May this year.

I have been a fan since they formed in the sixties, albeit as a young teenager. This year I am 50. What a present that would be, my sweetheart and I thought.

I saw in the Sunday Times that tickets were to go on sale from 9.00 am on Monday 31st January.

Despite being at work I arranged the net so that I was just into the ticket site, I had 2 mobiles with the number for the booking office at the RAH programmed in. At bang on 9.00 am I hit the dial on both and clicked the right buttons on the net.

Both phones were giving the engaged tone and the net was showing that the site was very busy and to try again later.

I dialled constantly on the mobiles for two and a half hours so much so that I am surprised that the little green and red phones were not completely worn off. Not once did I get anything other than the engaged tone. Colleagues in the office tried, same result.

The net was a no hoper, 'Very busy please try later' was the best I could get for over 2 hours.

Until at 11.30 the net worked I was into the site and there were tickets showing available, until you select how many you want, then the computer says no. It is probably sold out is the best advice the net can give!

However on E-Bay there were tickets being advertised at grossly inflated prices as little as one and a half hours after the lines and net opening. These were the people who stopped me getting through. People who had no intention of going to the concert and their sole aim was to gain.

Well I will not on principle pay those prices, I would hope that they catch a cold but doubt it.

If this is capitalist Britain I am glad that I can retire in a little over 3 years and leave.

I hope some real fans managed to get through and get tickets.

Greetings to Jack the Bruce: Praise God, Jack! The fact that somewhere between sessions with Cream you will read this note, is in itself reason to shout, 'I'm So Glad.' 'More God than Jack' your presence with us is a great kindness not only to yourself but to all of us who love you and your music. It seems only fitting that if one of your forefathers, Robert the Bruce,so titled due to fighting for political freedom, then like title befits one also who has fought for artistic freedom. Congradulations, mission accomplished.'Jack the Bruce' is well deserved. Not that the battle is over but this one thing you do, forgetting those things of the past,you press on engaging in the good fight of faith and musicianship. In like manner,passionate as well about musical excellence are your bandmates,Eric and Ginger. The synergy in Cream is clearly unequalled by any other band, then or now.The friendship formed decades ago stilldraws a total effort from each musician when playing together.Hence, the quality in music is magnified,not by the Marshalls but by the Spirit. Yet there is this growing attitude in each player-to extoll the talents of his bandmates more than his own.The Cream Team thereby propels itself to greater heights than ever before. " Do you see one gifted in his craft, he will stand before kings and not mere men." From all corners of the earth people of reknown will come to the Royal Albert Hall to enjoy the liberation of their spirits through Cream. Even Mickey the Fiddler, would trade in his violin to hear this band but once. The new material joining the old will, like Bach's works, go down in musical history as the best in its category. The early sellout testifies to the global thirst for original music and talent. Ticket Agencies recognized the huge potential for concert demand. Not surprisingly, sales even at 10times the RAH price are doing very well. A credit to Cream if not to the rapacious scalpers. I wish Jack, above all else, that you continue to prosper and be in good health, even as your soul prospers. May you, Eric and Ginger have the best of times together.

Gratefully, John Flanagan

COMMENTS

Mr. Bruce:

I'm about a decade younger than you, but I remember Cream in the mid/late 1960's, although I was too young to appreciate the music at that time.

Interestingly, when I thought of Cream over the ensuing years, I usually figured it was an "Eric Clapton band;" I knew your name and Ginger Baker's, of course, but more or less thought of Clapton when I thought of Cream.

Anyhow, I very recently picked up the 1991 DVD Cream retrospective and I've very much enjoyed watching and listening to the music, conversations, and insights.

There's no question Eric Clapton's a tremendously gifted guitarist, and I have a new and great appreciation for Ginger Baker and his work - but it's now clear to me that Cream was your band, from start to finish.

Your vocals (wailing and all) are so expressive that I can listen to them over and over; your bass guitar playing is very, very impressive, indeed; and your charisma and stage presence are riveting.

What particularly strikes me, however, is what you've done for the past almost four decades with your music - I found your website and read with great interest the different musical genres you've been involved in; you deserve much credit for being the truly great musician that you are.

Like everyone else, I'm certainly curious and excited to see what I hope will be a DVD from your 2005 Cream Reunion - and I'm sure it'll be wonderfully enjoyable for all.

But you are much, much more than Cream from a musical standpoint - and for that you should be honored and congratulated.

Very best personal regards.

Steve Erie
